Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was kneeling on the floor of Mrs. Patel’s living room, running my hand over the splintered joist, when my phone buzzed. The termite damage was worse than I’d feared—her house wasn’t safe, and she was counting on me to give her a repair plan before the end of the day. She hovered nearby, anxious, asking if her family would have to move out. I promised her I’d figure it out, but as I reached for my tape measure, my phone buzzed again. It was a legislative aide from Senator Kim’s office—finally calling back after weeks of emails. I had ten minutes, right now, to make my case for the housing bill I’d been fighting for. My mind raced: Mrs. Patel needed answers, but this call could change policy for hundreds of families like hers. I could see her watching me, hope and worry in her eyes, while my phone kept vibrating in my hand. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role I owed more in this moment, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in from all sides.
